meanings.definition: To assign a grade higher than deserved.
meanings.sent1: The teacher overgraded my test because she made a mistake.
meanings.sent2: I hope the teacher doesn't overgrade my assignment and give me a higher score than I earned.
meanings.sent3: It would be funny if the teacher accidentally overgraded everyone's homework and we all got A's.
meanings.sent4: She tends to overgrade her students, making them think they are better at the subject than they actually are.
meanings.sent5: The danger of overgrading is that students may not realize their true level of understanding.

meanings.definition: To evaluate or rate too highly.
meanings.sent1: The critic overgraded the movie, giving it a perfect score even though it had many flaws.
meanings.sent2: It's important not to overgrade someone's performance and provide constructive feedback instead.
meanings.sent3: It would be amusing if the judge accidentally overgraded all the contestants in the talent show.
meanings.sent4: She tends to overgrade restaurants, thinking every place she visits is the best she's ever been to.
meanings.sent5: Overgrading can lead to unrealistic expectations and disappointment in the long run.

meanings.sent1: The librarian overgraded the book, placing it in the wrong section of the library.
meanings.sent2: It's easy to overgrade items when organizing, so it's important to double-check your work.
meanings.sent3: It would be strange if the museum curator overgraded the historical artifacts and displayed them incorrectly.
meanings.sent4: She tends to overgrade the importance of certain documents, causing confusion among the staff.
meanings.sent5: Overgrading can lead to chaos and misplacement of valuable items.
